BECAUSE I LIKED YOU BETTER

Because I liked you better
Than suits a man to say,
It irked you, and I promised
To throw the thought away.

To put the world between us
We parted, stiff and dry;
'Good-bye,' said you, 'forget me.'
'I will, no fear', said I.

If here, where clover whitens
The dead man's knoll, you pass,
And no tall flower to meet you
Starts in the trefoiled grass,

Halt by the headstone naming
The heart no longer stirred,
And say the lad that loved you
Was one that kept his word.

— A.E.Houseman

posts.name: Anonymouṡ
posts.com:
>>21380949

TOADS

Why should I let the toad *work*
Squat on my life?
Can’t I use my wit as a pitchfork
And drive the brute off?

Six days of the week it soils
With its sickening poison —
Just for paying a few bills!
That’s out of proportion.

Lots of folk live on their wits:
Lecturers, lispers,
Losels, loblolly-men, louts —
They don’t end as paupers;

Lots of folk live up lanes
With fires in a bucket,
Eat windfalls and tinned sardines —
They seem to like it.

Their nippers have got bare feet,
Their unspeakable wives
Are skinny as whippets — and yet
No one actually *starves*.

Ah, were I courageous enough
To shout *Stuff your pension!*
But I know, all too well, that’s the stuff
That dreams are made on:

For something sufficiently toad-like
Squats in me, too;
Its hunkers are heavy as hard luck,
And cold as snow,

And will never allow me to blarney
My way to getting
The fame and the girl and the money
All at one sitting.

I don’t say, one bodies the other
One’s spiritual truth;
But I do say it’s hard to lose either,
When you have both.

— Philip Larkin

posts.name: Anonymouṡ
posts.com:
>>21380949

LAMENT

When I was a windy boy and a bit
And the black spit of the chapel fold,
(Sighed the old ram rod, dying of women),
I tiptoed shy in the gooseberry wood,
The rude owl cried like a tell-tale tit,
I skipped in a blush as the big girls rolled
Nine-pin down on the donkey's common,
And on seesaw Sunday nights I wooed
Whoever I would with my wicked eyes,
The whole of the moon I could love and leave
All the green leaved little weddings' wives
In the coal black bush and let them grieve.

When I was a gusty man and a half
And the black beast of the beetles' pews
(Sighed the old ram rod, dying of bitches),
Not a boy and a bit in the wick-dipping moon
And drunk as a new dropped calf,
I whistled all night in the twisted flues,
Midwives grew in the midnight ditches,
And the sizzling beds of the town cried, Quick!
Whenever I dove in a breast high shoal,
Wherever I ramped in the clover quilts,
Whatsoever I did in the coal-black night,
I left my quivering prints.

When I was a man you could call a man
And the black cross of the holy house,
(Sighed the old ram rod, dying of welcome),
Brandy and ripe in my bright, bass prime,
No springtailed tom in the red hot town
With every simmering woman his mouse
But a hillocky bull in the swelter
Of summer come in his great good time
To the sultry, biding herds, I said.
Oh, time enough when the blood seeps cold,
And I lie down but to sleep in bed,
For my sulking, skulking, coal black soul!

When I was a half the man I was
And served me right as the preachers warn,
(Sighed the old ram rod, dying of downfall),
No flailing calf or cat in a flame
Or hickory bull in milky grass
But a black sheep with a crumpled horn,
At last the soul from its foul mousehole
Slunk pouting out when the limp time came;
And I gave my soul a blind, slashed eye,
Gristle and rind, and a roarers' life,
And I shoved it into the coal black sky
To find a woman's soul for a wife.

Now I am a man no more no more
And a black reward for a roaring life,
(Sighed the old ram rod, dying of strangers).
Tidy and cursed in my dove cooed room
I lie down thin and hear the good bells jaw —
For, oh, my soul found a sunday wife
In the coal black sky and she bore angels!
Harpies around me out of her womb!
Chastity prays for me, piety sings,
Innocence sweetens my last black breath,
Modesty hides my thighs in her wings,
And all the deadly virtues plague my death!

— Dylan Thomas

SHEEP IN FOG

The hills step off into whiteness.
People or stars
Regard me sadly, I disappoint them.

The train leaves a line of breath.
O slow
Horse the colour of rust,

Hooves, dolorous bells —
All morning the
Morning has been blackening,

A flower left out.
My bones hold a stillness, the far
Fields melt my heart.

They threaten
To let me through to a heaven
Starless and fatherless, a dark water.

— Sylvia Plath

SHINE, PERISHING REPUBLIC

While this America settles in the mould of its vulgarity, heavily thickening to empire
And protest, only a bubble in the molten mass, pops and sighs out, and the mass hardens,

I sadly smiling remember that the flower fades to make fruit, the fruit rots to make earth.
Out of the mother; and through the spring exultances, ripeness and decadence; and home to the mother.

You making haste haste on decay: not blameworthy; life is good, be it stubbornly long or suddenly
A mortal splendor: meteors are not needed less than mountains: shine, perishing republic.

But for my children, I would have them keep their distance from the thickening center; corruption
Never has been compulsory, when the cities lie at the monster's feet there are left the mountains.

And boys, be in nothing so moderate as in love of man, a clever servant, insufferable master.
There is the trap that catches noblest spirits, that caught — they say — God, when he walked on earth.

— Robinson Jeffers

>>21373688
The Traditionalist critique of Christianity is that it's a merely sentimental/moral religion, that the highest one can achieve within it is a vague mystical state (as Evola says, merely ecstatic and passive, without post-ecstatic and active "re-entry" into one's self, completing the self-conscious initiation process), and also that ANY AND ALL historical and eschatological events or revelations (like God giving his unique revelation to Moses, and later Christ's redemption, but also the ongoing fight against Satan's influence in this world) are inadmissible from a Traditional standpoint - because history means nothing from the Traditional standpoint, which is anti-eschatological, regarding eschatologies as particularist and exclusivist tribal myths that have become dogmas. Essentially, Traditionalism's critique of Christianity is very similar to the Theravada critique of Mahayana Buddhism's soteriological and eschatological elements.

But these criticisms potentially force Traditionalism itself into a passive and quietistic position, which it is supposedly criticizing Christianity for. If there is no collective mystery or collective quest for redemption or struggle against Satan, if religions can't have an eschatological, soteriological, world historical character, because the only real truth lies in the universal metaphysical truth attained through individual initiation, then why bother fighting the occult war at all? In fact this is where a lot of Guenonians end up, advocating just riding out the kali yuga because it's all cyclical anyway. If your conception of all human dealings, all history, is simply that it is samsara, with no teleological or eschatology, then your only two options for understanding samsara are (1) it's an uncreated and "static" eternal world, like Aristotle's world, or (2) it cyclically dies and is reborn, and presumably there is some symbolically "fixed" number and nature to the ages of the cycle and so on and so forth, but again all this means nothing, since as an individual initiate you cannot affect the cycles in any way, or perhaps at most you can accelerate the present one (?).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21373691
What is even the value in seeking to create a "diamond/rainbow body" and escape samsara at all? Why seek immortality? Why desire to order society according to divine models if it's all cyclical or indifferent anyway? Guenon and Evola both emphasize that there is nothing "moral" in what they are doing, and that the vulgar sentimental and moral religion of everyday faithful is merely exoteric, basically its only value is containing dumbed down versions of symbols that keep ordinary people anchored in their Traditional-Platonic republics, while maintaining pathways of symbolic ascent for talented individuals to pursue to their eventual initiation. But again, why? Unless there is some real, non-cylical, zero-sum struggle going on, then who cares? Why do things even happen contingently in history, like Evola says when he says that it's bizarre that such a sentimental religion took hold in the "active" West, if everything is cyclical?

It seems to me like there are contradictions in the Traditionalist worldview, because it wants to take history seriously, it wants to take the occult war seriously, it wants to be active in the world (except for some extreme Guenonians), it has or wants to have an eschatology, but it can't admit this to itself because it views all of these things as inadmissible in pure metaphysics. It's a bit like modern science in this way: science is unwilling to envision anything metaphysical, because it's obsessed with not tainting itself with superstitions. Similarly Traditionalism doesn't want to taint itself with mere samsaric, dogmatic, sentimental, tribal superstitions. But just like modern science closes itself off to genuine truths and opportunities, Traditionalism closes itself off to non-jnana possibilities that are more interesting than it imagines.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21373693
For example, it closes itself off to angelology and demonology, to the idea that on higher metaphysical planes there are beings beyond the human (at least in part) who are both good and evil. Ironically it ends up "confusing the planes" itself, by assuming that the only thing between man and the Absolute is this metaphysical hierarchy of symbols, and that there are no other beings with plans for us, that the cosmos is a cyclically autorenewing stage on which a few Guenons and Evolas periodically become immortal (for what? where do they go? if it's just to a purified paradisiacal state, isn't that what they criticize Christianity for promising?). Most major traditions have some form of angelology/demonology, whether Neoplatonic or Christian, pre-Islamic djinn, Buddhist demonology, etc. From a Traditionalist perspective, a Christian or Neoplatonic angelology that emphasizes faith in and collaboration with Good beings who are actively engaged in an eschatological fight, an occult war, and who both want to help us and who want our help, would just be superstition. But from a Christian perspective, and from a Neoplatonic or even Mahayana perspective that takes the occult war seriously, Traditionalism would be dangerously "magical" in trying to be an amoral series of techniques, and advice for the maintenance of said techniques in initiatic lines, in a cosmos in which active participation in soteriological eschatology is a necessary element of any awakening, and in which demonic forces are equally active. From this perspective, Evola and Guenon would be doing exactly what they criticize New Agers for doing: stripping people of their everyday protections and throwing them into trans-personal psychic experiences in which they will simply be subject to whatever forces are nearby.

In rejecting all claims to revelation as contingent and samsaric, Traditionalism also misses out on the possibility of a symbolic interpretation of "dispensationalist" revelation, in which history is not merely samsaric and cyclical, and attaining enlightenment is not merely optional and always potentially open to amoral initiates, and the occult war is not merely a particularly bad patch in the most recent kali yuga in an infinite cycle of them, but instead, history is not cylical, there is a fixed goal here, there are win and lose conditions, enlightenment is not just "available" to initiates but is a responsibility and a duty, and thus enabling others to be enlightened is also a duty, etc.

>>21373697
And therefore, the mythic-eschatological content of a religion like Christianity, with its publically available emphasis on resisting Satan and imitating Christ in daily life, is not just an incidental exoteric form of symbols that are only really relevant to autistic initiates, there is actually a purpose to the "opening" of the mysteries, which, yes, vulgarized them from a certain perspective, but perhaps only because this was analogous to sprinkling thousands of seeds, formerly been contained in neatly condensed form in individual pots, over a huge field of soil and manure, so that at first they seem merely "lost," but in time they grow and become many thousands of fruit-bearing, seed-bearing trees themselves?

If all of history can be interpreted symbolically in this way, then we can begin to ask questions that the Traditionalists are afraid to ask: What does it MEAN, using symbolic interpretation and sympathetic intuition, that Christ figures appeared and managed to embed moral messages and fundamentally change history, turning pagan Europe into a moral and even sentimental Christian Europe - which Evola can only view as an aberration, from his Traditionalist perspective? What does it MEAN that analogous developments occurred in India, with Mahayana and other soteriological movements introducing new ideas into the stagnant and formalistic ritualistic cults? If this is all just samsaric "noise," (1) why would there be any "noise" that diverges from the cyclical norm, and (2) why care at all? It's just a blip in the cycle.

Traditionalist metaphysics in my view also has an impoverished account of metaphysical personality and of the metaphysics of freedom, but I've already written too much, sorry about that. But I find the dismissal of the encounter of personal beings in mystical states incomplete and even lazy. The "scientific" starkness of Traditionalism is very useful insofar as it burns away all the dangerous dross of, for example, Blavatsky's Theosophy's blind faith in its Masters of Wisdom, or Steiner's endless visionary claims with no proof. But it should have been a clearing and a praeparatio evangelica, not a self-sufficient technique to end all techniques. Overall I think Traditionalism needs a re-fertilization by all the traditions it rejects: Abrahamic, Zoroastrian, and Hindu bhakti. Its extreme rejection of personal, moral, eschatological, and soteriological elements was historically conditioned by the dangerous spread of New Age syncretism and occultism that led to people like Crowley (probably genuinely dangerous, as can be seen in Scientology). This process should be oriented toward fighting the occult war in a moral, soteriological, eschatological way. The presupposition of autistic initiation and meaningless cyclical samsara should be dropped, and the "merely accidental" elements of traditions (that is, that don't accord with autistic initiation and meaningless cyclicality) should be reinterpreted in this light.

>>21373703

This ties into the poverty of the Traditionalist understanding of personality and freedom: they only see these as sources or vehicles of contingency, to be purged so that the higher self can be brought forth, transcending contingency and leaving samsara. But personality and freedom are symbolically analogous to history: apparent contingency that can contain or reflect symbolic truth. Traditionalism sees all three of these categories in a merely negative way, each is interpreted as mere caprice or as the negative pole of manifestation of essence. But if the nature of all being is that of essence, which is pure in itself but which struggles to manifest clearly in becoming, then why shouldn't becoming itself (and its subordinate aspects: personality, freedom, history) have its own essence and meaning? Why not interpret ALL temporal contingency, all becoming qua "mere negation of, or derivation or divagation from, atemporal being," as itself the symbolic emanation of an essence that combines and explains both being and becoming, instead of merely LEAVING becoming as an empty/negative category as almost all nondualist metaphysicians, including Traditionalists, do? This inquiry would allow us to ask all the questions Traditionalists can't ask from within their own framework:
>Why does samsara/maya (the totality of Becoming as the mirror of the totality of Being) exist at all?
>Why do individual Persons (individual monads of Becoming, strung between equal possibilities of self-distancing from Being or self-purification and ascent to Being, undecidable except by the individual Person) exist at all, as distinct from the spheres of emanation?
>Why do individual souls perceive themselves as free (the right to Become Being, or not to Become non-Being, undecidable except by the Person)?
>What is the nature of non-human souls (monads of Becoming with higher grades of Being)?
>What is the nature of God (the Being that mirrors itself in Becoming), and why is Free Personality (the right to Become etc.) among the elements that stems from God, if it has no Being and no meaning?
while using the Traditionalists' refined methods of sympathetic symbolic intuition, just training it on the one symbol they most neglect.

>>21382003
Read Evola and you'll find out. I can't and won't summarise everything for you. What I can tell you is that Evola already had major gripes with the Jewish prophetic tradition, which is the deepest root of Christianity. The key to understanding the prophetic tradition is to acknowledge two things - first, that it belongs to a very profane culture, and second, that it originates from the lowest social stratum of that culture. So, whereas (at least the best) rabbis and Jewish kings had their own spiritual and royal arts, the prophets were mostly very pious and coarse bums. Their spirituality was that of a man who feels a strong, strong love for divinity, but also, due to his coarse mentality and special psychological features, fails to discover the presence of the divine element anywhere at all. Hence the difference between the Greeks who admired the world as a reflection of the divine world of forms on the one hand, and the Jewish prophets on the other hand, with the famous cry "vanitas vanitatum". In the prophetic view, God is the only thing of value, and he is not to be found anywhere, least of all within ourselves. Hence the fundamentally shattered and broken nature of man, who needs "redemption", and, what is more, faith in order to be redeemed. From this stems also the very flawed "solution, at every level - you just need to be rendered "complete" by "God". Orthodoxy provides the most successful formulation of this with the idea of the Godbearing man, and also of Theosis, but even that stops short of true metaphysical heights. God is beyond all form, beyond all manifestation and beyond any completeness or completing function. To unite with God means more than to honour him in your heart - it means to become one with him, literally, and consequently also transcend everything, as he does. That's henosis. If you don't reach that level, you are still dealing with manifestation rather than with the source, the essence.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21380249
No, often times you will approach and agency and one of things they'll look at is what your social media presence/following is like. Agencies want people who can advertise on their own. The idea that they do it all for you is dated. Nowadays most books that agencies pick up don't sell for shit because they don't do advertising, the authors have no following, and the general populace doesn't read enough for middling books to get big organically. If you can't advertise yourself and you're a white male writing in a saturated genre like fantasy, for instance, they're not going to give you a second look unless you're selling yourself on your own social media. And at that point the self-publishing industry is robust enough that you can do the whole thing on your own. Which is exactly why traditional publishing is a rapidly dying industry.

>Alfred Edward Housman (26 March 1859 – 30 April 1936) was an English classical scholar and poet. His cycle of poems, A Shropshire Lad, wistfully evokes the constraints and limited choices of youth in the English countryside. The simplicity and distinctive imagery of the writing appealed strongly to Edwardian taste, and to many early 20th-century English composers, both before and after the First World War. Through their song-settings, the poems became closely associated with that era, and with Shropshire itself.
>Housman was one of the foremost classicists of his age and has been ranked as one of the greatest scholars at any time. He established his reputation publishing as a private scholar at first and, on the strength and quality of his work, was appointed Professor of Latin at University College London and then at the University of Cambridge. His editions of Juvenal, Manilius and Lucan are still considered authoritative.

posts.com:
Have you read it?
What did you think?
Is it true? Why/why not?
I’ll start
>have you read it
… no
>what did you think of it?
well it’s a very challenging letter to read as a Christian, because it clearly points out that I live in darkness and I have not seen the light. I think it’s a very uplifting message though, because John is writing from the light and writes to everyone in the whole world so they may see the light as well. I think in the initial part of the letter, it seems as though he is writing from heaven. I think John wrote with divine inspiration.
>That which we have seen and heard we report also to you that you also may have fellowship with us, and indeed our fellowship is with the Father and with His Son Jesus Christ.
His tone is very welcoming and it seems like I am entering the fellowship of sanctified people when I read this letter, because of the way John wrote it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21382119
>Is it true? Why/why not?
I think it is true, because John is writing it all with his eyes firmly set on Jesus, who is truth. I also think it’s true because of how cutting the words in it are. Only the truth can tear you apart like the words in this letter. I don’t say it cuts to make it out to be a horrendous thing. The cuts are surgical. John wrote truly so we Christians could live as we ought to live, walking even as He walked. The truth of the way of Christ…
>And this is the message which we have heard from Him and announce to you, that God is light and in Him is no darkness at all. If we say that we have fellowship with Him and yet walk in the darkness, we lie and are not practicing the truth; But if we walk in the light as He is in the light, we have fellowship with one another, and the blood of Jesus His Son cleanses us from every sin. If we say that we do not have sin, we are deceiving ourselves, and the truth is not in us. If we confess our sins, He is faithful and righteous to forgive us our sins and cleanse us from all unrighteousness. If we say that we have not sinned, we make Him a liar, and His word is not in us.
This is true because it gets to the very core of your being and it is simple enough for any man to understand. I think something true ought to be simple enough for everyone to realise, not a convoluted philosophy. If you have sinned, you have walked in the darkness and have not known Jesus. If you confess your sins, you are cleansed by the blood of Jesus and walk in the light even as He walked in the light, and it is the true light of God, not physical light. I think the true way of being a Christian is therefore continuous confession, to receive continuous cleansing and continuous fellowship with Jesus Christ, but it also takes love to be in fellowship with Jesus Christ, and if you have not loved the brothers, who you have seen, you cannot love Jesus, who you have not seen. This is another cutting word of the epistle for me. I have not loved my brothers. I have hated them, and I have not loved Jesus, I have only loved myself. It is a terrible realisation to make as a Christian that I have not loved Jesus in deed or truthfulness, but only in saying and in tongue. With my lips I was close to Him but my heart I have kept far from him. It’s scary to be so honest with myself, but it is true, and I need to confess this to be cleansed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21382120
That’s why I think the epistle of John is really one of the best letters you can read from the Bible, because it will take all the wind from your sails and remind you how powerful and loving Jesus Christ is that he could love everyone with perfect love and never hate and live his life that way unto eternity, and that as Christians it is our honour to follow Him along that way. We should not be hateful nor sinful, if we are truly on the way. I think this is another reason why the letter is so good. If we say to ourselves as Christians that we are on the way of Christ, why do we hate our brothers? If you hate your brother, Christian, you are not on the way. Again, this is such a simple truth, and it’s why I think the words written in it are true, for those who believe.

>>21380605
Good books but don't get caught up in the business of making lists / curriculums for yourself. You'll find that you end up wanting to read other things that aren't on your list, and will lose interest in good books that you'd otherwise enjoy. You could honestly watch a few videos on Greek mythology before jumping right into the Iliad instead of spending time reading ample time reading about them as a primer.

Also the Bible should be set aside as it's own study, not as a complementary piece of a Greek lit reading list. You will extract more value from the OT alone than all Greek lit combined.

"Atheism" emerged as a grassroots ideology. The central premise was simple: you are only allowed to believe in something that you can prove via reason and empiricism. This ideology was constructed by nerds on the late-90s to early-2000s internet, particularly in opposition to the comedic stupidity of the Republican "Moral Majority" ideology/philosophy of the Reagan/Bush/Clinton/Bush administrations. Around 2007 or so, a faction split off. This faction, in essence, believed that Atheism meant a rejection of Liberalism. When this turned out not to be the case (the Democrats began to takeup ant-Christian rhetoric at this time), this faction left and became what we now know as the Alt Right. There's more to be said about the genealogy here, but we aren't talking about these guys.

This left "nuAtheism", which maintained the emphasis on rational argumentation (to absurdity). ElevatorGate happened in 2011, which raised a question for nuAtheists: should a man be allowed to ask a woman out on a date? This killed nuAtheism. Half said "yes", leading to Cultural Christians and a resurgence of Libertarians (this is where Dawkins ended up btw), the other half said "no", and became SJWs.

In as much as American Protestantism is dead in the water (Q was the final nail in the coffin), Atheism (the first sort) has won, and is the dominant paradigm in Western politics.

Achilles was annoyed that his honour was insulted. He didn’t care about Briseis as a person. That’s a very modern interpretation necessary to make the movie acceptable to contemporary audiences. As for the question of homosexuality, we don’t know what Homer intended, but the Greeks were pretty unanimous in their interpretation:
>I shall speak first about Homer, whom we rank among the oldest and wisest of the poets. He mentions Patroklos and Achilles in many places, but he keeps their erotic love hidden and the proper name of their friendship, thinking that the exceptional extent of their affection made things clear to the educated members of his audience.
Aeschines, Against Timarchos 142-3

>Aeschylus talks nonsense in claiming that Achilles was in love with Patroclus (rather than the other way around), for Achilles was more beautiful than not only Patroclus but all the other heroes as well; and besides, he was unbearded, and thirdly, far younger than Patroclus, as Homer says. Well, anyhow, though the gods really hold in very high esteem that virtue which concerns love, they wonder, admire, band confer benefits even more when the beloved has affection for the lover than when the lover has it for the beloved.
Plato, Symposium 179e-180b

>And you did not respect the chaste consecration of the thighs, oh ungrateful that you were for those countless kisses!
Aeschylus, Myrmidons, Fragment 135

>I honored the intimacy of your thighs by bewailing you
Aeschylus, Myrmidons, Fragment 136

>No, pleasure was the mediator even of their friendship. At any rate, when Achilles was lamenting the death of Patroclus, his unrestrained feelings made him burst out with the truth and say "The converse of our thighs my tears do mourn with duteous piety."
Ps-Lucian, Amores 54

>Love affairs were such an open and everyday matter that the great poet Aeschylus, and Sophocles too, put sexual themes on the stage in their tragedies, Aeschylus showing Achilles’ love for Patroclus.
Athenaeus 13.601

Only Xenophon seems to voice disagreement in his version of the Symposium, where he has his Socrates take issue with it. Shakespeare also seems to depict them as lovers, or at least as suspected lovers, in Troilus and Cressida

>>21378959
That was one of the themes of Homer in general, but rather that there was tension within the aristocratic greek culture because the warlords here were nominally equal. Agamemnon was prideful and declared himself king of kings, but the Argive chiefs constantly engaged in sacrifices and rituals that established their equality as a warrior aristocracy. That is why Achilles was enraged, because he insisted Agamemnon was encroaching on his rights and that Agamemnon had no basis for doing so because his superiority wasn't founded on anything.

Though I shouldn't really use the word "rights". Nobody granted the rights, but by custom Achilles had already claimed his share of the spoils and Agamemnon abridged what under custom was recognized as Achilles'. So he shamed Achilles, and Achilles took the opportunity to abandon the war. Like another Anon said, the other big theme is of destiny or fate, which is a constant theme in much Greek myth. Fate is a nice tool to contextualize values and human agency, since Achilles knowledge of his death in the war means he has to decide what matters to him. It contextualizes his rage over the death of Patroclus, his choice to return to the war and face death for personal vengeance against Hector. He never respected Agamemnon's authority, Achilles was classically heroic because he was deeply honorable. His actions show he was neither Agamemnon's slave nor a coward, he went to his death to avenge his friend/partner and nothing else.

It was only their children if fathered by a member of the higher classes who stood chance of being raised in status.

This use of slave women was not done because it was natural, we cannot make such a claim as the peasant classes of Homer's world are never mentioned. Their customs are entirely unknown to us, but the ruling classes used this method of fathering children though slaves to bolster their strength. Telemachus was unable to secure his position against the suitors in Ithaca because he had no blood brothers to aid him, so families with as many blood related sons as possible were stronger for it.

>>21379412
Yes! I'm glad some people here know the Greeks. Particularly, I don't think many modern people seem to read the Odyssey and really question what is going on with Telemachus and Penelope. It might just be the archaic way it is all written, but it seems like people glaze over at that. The suitors both don't need Penelope and do need her to take possession of Ithaca. Penelope isn't the "heir" of Ithaca per se, Odysseus inherited the throne through his father and Penelope is just his wife, but Telemachus is not the one in charge of the household either because he doesn't seek to claim it, he believes his father lives. It is just de facto the case that Penelope is the one who represents the household of Odysseus and the closest position to the power over Ithaca, so the suitors compete with each other for Ithaca by competing over Penelope. She just finds herself in the position of being the means to claim some legitimacy over Ithaca.

But also as you said, while I think Telemachus doesn't want to claim power over Ithaca because on some level this could be seen as a betrayal of his father, or a challenge to him (the situation could get sticky if Odysseus returns), he also simply doesn't feel secure enough to do so. There are tons of adult men in Odysseus' house who have many friends and kinsmen who would fight on their side, and Telemachus doesn't feel capable of opposing them. This is the flip side to him potentially feeling conflicted about claiming the household for himself, what if the suitors simply try to kill him and take Ithaca? Suppose his father returns, he would find that his incapable son lost everything. So ultimately Penelope and Telemachus are of the same understanding that the best thing to do is stall for time and try to find Odysseus.

Unironically, strongly patriarchal cultures often express their glorification of masculinity through homosexual behavior. They don't always, it isn't some necessary condition of patriarchy, but it happens in multiple cultures throughout history and doesn't seem like a coincidence. Consider how the companionship of women can become devalued by their general status as tools for powerful men to trade between each other. Women are still arousing, but even in this capacity they can easily be equated to slave women and prostitutes who are just objectified for their qualities of being arousing.

So the female sex in general becomes partially sub-human, they're just the inferiors of men. The test of companionship for women becomes their loyalty to you, but their loyalty is expected of them and isn't exactly valuable as something given to you. Greeks in Homer still showed strong signs of being a gift giving culture, since the aristocracy proudly gave, received and displayed gifts as signs of respect and alliance. In the Iliad there were even cases where somebody would recognize somebody else as a friend because their fathers had exchanged gifts. Gift giving is done between, roughly speaking, people who are equals, and it displays how you are valued by others when they freely give you gifts.

The loyalty of a wife in a culture as patriarchal as the Homeric Greeks was not a gift given by the wife, she owes loyalty as a member of the patriarch's household. But the loyalty and devotion of a man can really inspire pride, because men can be equals in honor. So the relationship between men can take on a deeper value. That isn't to then say that love between men and women in the way we understand it as a kind of companionship of "equals" was unheard of, but it was usually very ambiguously presented as something like intense lust. But male companionship wasn't as sullied by the quality of women as sexual objects that brought houses together in alliance. So it is easy to see how it can paradoxically (for us) appear as "masculine" to have semi-sexual companionship with men, because it is like an equal is giving themselves to you freely. But there are still tensions around dominance and who is giving to who, so you also get the common element of the older man and the younger man who is often something like an "apprentice" to the older man (see the gay samurai too).

But compared to Leiber, Howard, Dunsany, Eddison, Kipling, Haggard, Peake, Mieville, or Moorcock, Wolfe is nothing special.

Perhaps I just got my hopes up too high. I imagined something that might evoke Peake or Leiber (at his best), perhaps with a complexity and depth gesturing toward Milton or Ariosto. I could hardly imagine a better book than that, but even a book half that good would be a delight--or a book that was nothing like that, but was unpredictable and seductive in some other way.

I kept waiting for something to happen, but it never really did. It all plods along without much rise or fall, just the constant moving action to make us think something interesting is happening. I did find some promise, some moments that I would have loved to see the author explore, particularly those odd moments where Silver Age Sci Fi crept in, but each time he touched upon these, he would return immediately to the smallness of his plot and his annoying prick of a narrator. I never found the book to be difficult or complex, merely tiring. the unusual parts were evasive and vague, and the dull parts constant and repetitive.

The whole structure (or lack of it) does leave things up to interpretation, and perhaps that's what some readers find appealing: that they can superimpose their own thoughts and values onto the narrator, and onto the plot itself. But at that point, they don't like the book Wolfe wrote, they like the book they are writing between his lines.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21380033
Then there is the fact that every character you meet in the story turns up again, hundreds of miles away, to reveal that they are someone else and have been secretly controlling the action of the plot. It feels like the entire world is populated by about fifteen people who follow the narrator around wherever he goes. If the next two books continue along the same lines, then the big reveal will be that the world is entirely populated by no more than three superpowered shapeshifters.

Everyone in the book has secret identities, secret connections to grand conspiracies, and important plot elements that they conveniently hide until the last minute, only doling out clues here and there. There are no normal people in this world, only double agents and kings in disguise. Every analysis I've read of this book mentions that even the narrator is unreliable.

This can be an effective technique, but in combination with a world of infinite, unpredictable intrigue, Wolfe's story begins to evoke something between a soap opera and a convoluted mystery novel, relying on impossible and contradictory scenarios to mislead the audience. Apparently, this is the thing his fans most appreciate about him--I find it to be an insulting and artificial game.

I agree with this reviewer that there is simply not enough structure to the story to make the narrator's unreliability meaningful. In order for unreliable narration to be effective, there must be some clear and evident counter-story that undermines it. Without that, it is not possible to determine meaning, because there's nowhere to start: everything is equally shaky.

At that point, it's just a trick--adding complexity to the surface of the story without actually producing any new meaning. I know most sci fi and fantasy authors seem to love complexity for its own sake, but it's a cardinal sin of storytelling: don't add something into your story unless it needs to be there. Covering the story with a lot of vagaries and noise may impress some, but won't stand up to careful reading.

>I wish Stella Maris was chopped up and plugged into this book in a sensible way though.
I think CM originally tried to do that, basically, but it was all too big and tangled as a single novel.

If you wanted to do it, I think the best shot would be to have Alicia's talks with the Kid in strict order [i.e. Chicago farewell last] followed by her Stella Maris transcripts, all interleaved with Bobby's story in 1980+. You could stick with Alicia's suicide as the very first thing but then go straight to Bobby's dive to the plane. (Starting The Passenger with a prologue and then a chapter, both in italics, was not good, in my opinion. You want to alternate italics & normal.) That way you just have two timelines, alternating. Not sure if you want to end with the last Stella Maris transcript or Bobby's last thoughts.

You would probably want to shrink/compress the Alicia-Kid talks, if you're adding SM. That would be OK with me since they get a bit annoying anyway.

>Very isolating story for me. Chapter X was ridiculously melancholic. One line above all others has stuck with me from this book, trying to understand its meaning.

>“And when they crash through the walls howling?”

Ever since the border trilogy Cormac's books have been saying that Bad Times Are A-Coming. I think he genuinely believes that Western civilization is on the way out and we're going back to a cruder, more savage existence. He uses Mexico (or, more generally, Latin America) as the symbol of what will prevail:

— Cities of the Plain
When Eduardo taunts John Grady at the end, he says, more-or-less, "we [i.e. Mexico] will bury you".

— No Country For Old Men
It's right there in the title. And it's basically all Bell talks about.

— The Counselor
"The slaughter to come is probably beyond our imagining" says Malkina in the final scene. She's the ruthless hunter who is going to inherit the earth, and where's she from? Argentina. The "civilized" USA is going down. The Couselor himself is basically the average smug American normie, and he sleepwalks to destruction. Brad Pitt's character is more aware of how things really are, but this doesn't save him. (What's his name? Westray.)

Malkina is quite up-front with Reiner about this. "When the axe comes through the door, I'll already be gone, you know that?" Very similar to the line you quoted. CM really believes there are violent forces being held at bay which must eventually break through.


In The Passenger, everyone Bobby talks to expresses the same idea:

"The horrors of the past lose their edge, and in the doing they blind us to a world careening towards a darkness beyond the bitterest speculation."
— Sheddan, Chapter V

"Have you looked around lately, Son? What do you think is coming? Christmas?"
— Borman, Chapter VI

"You think his patience is infinite? I think we're probably almost there. I think the odds are on that we'll still be here to see him wet his thumb and lean over and unscrew the sun."
— Jeffrey, Chapter VIII

The difference is that now it's on a cosmic, religious scale, rather than a civilizational one. Alicia is hyper-sensitive to this, so she actually hallucinates demons at the gate, waiting their moment. She sees literally what Cormac himself sees metaphorically. Bobby doesn't see it quite as she does, but in the line you quote, he's remembering what she said and thinking she might be right.

posts.com:
Let's discuss the works and ideas of Alexis de Tocqueville.
Post your favorite passages, quotes, etc.

“What good does it do me, after all, if an ever-watchful authority keeps an eye out to ensure that my pleasures will be tranquil and races ahead of me to ward off all danger, sparing me the need even to think about such things, if that authority, even as it removes the smallest thorns from my path, is also absolute master of my liberty and my life; if it monopolizes vitality and existence to such a degree that when it languishes, everything around it must also languish; when it sleeps, everything must also sleep; and when it dies, everything must also perish?

There are some nations in Europe whose inhabitants think of themselves in a sense as colonists, indifferent to the fate of the place they live in. The greatest changes occur in their country without their cooperation. They are not even aware of precisely what has taken place. They suspect it; they have heard of the event by chance. More than that, they are unconcerned with the fortunes of their village, the safety of their streets, the fate of their church and its vestry. They think that such things have nothing to do with them, that they belong to a powerful stranger called “the government.” They enjoy these goods as tenants, without a sense of ownership, and never give a thought to how they might be improved. They are so divorced from their own interests that even when their own security and that of their children is finally compromised, they do not seek to avert the danger themselves but cross their arms and wait for the nation as a whole to come to their aid. Yet as utterly as they sacrifice their own free will, they are no fonder of obedience than anyone else. They submit, it is true, to the whims of a clerk, but no sooner is force removed than they are glad to defy the law as a defeated enemy. Thus one finds them ever wavering between servitude and license.

When a nation has reached this point, it must either change its laws and mores or perish, for the well of public virtue has run dry: in such a place one no longer finds citizens but only subjects.”

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: you can practice for decades and never become good at writing. there are no functional rules, and there is no way to teach an individual the skills necessary to create a literary masterpiece. other crafts are different because you're not comparing like with like. broaden the given craft to its origin, and you'll see that it functions much the same as an open-ended repository for the individual's pursuit of an ideal.

>broaden the given craft to its origin, and you'll see that it functions much the same as an open-ended repository for the individual's pursuit of an ideal.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21378151
in my naive opinion, that is what art is fundamentally. the manifestation of the individual's pursuit of the ideal. the closer one comes to realizing the ideal, the better the art (usually). think of the art as a byproduct, instead of the goal, and you'll start to understand what i mean. A person looks to simply comprehend a thing, (anything from a glass of water to the concept of love itself is a valid pursued ideal) and in so doing, they leave a sort of husk of their transformed selves or their environments in the process of refining that ideal. it's the only definition i've ever felt is open enough to describe art in the grand sense, since anything from someone gyrating their hips to a sequence of unrecorded thought can and has been considered art.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>21378223
>Writing and begging for feedback at every step is a cuckold move and shows that one is writing for personal gratification and affirmation of their ego and NOT for the simple pleasure that one derives from being a wordcel.

I think that's important. You'll never really feel validated either, because that cycle just repeats. You need to have your own standards and tastes or some sort of 'goal' or metric by wish to measure success and shoot for that.
I think eventually there will be a time to share the work and find someone who will be able to understand what you have tried to do and will be equipped to judge it with your goals in mind, but that is potentially far down the road.
That said I also think the idea of the lone genius hammering at his soul in isolation is a bit of a myth too and doesn't need to be the only way. History is full of writing groups. The key is just to have a group of likeminded people of similar abilities who have sympathy for the goals and sensibilities of the other people in the group and don't need to push their own ways and egos onto others, which can be damaging and limiting, for both the one giving the advice and the one receiving it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21378106
>Seriously, how do you git gud?
You have to have an internal conception of what gud is. It has to be intuitive, otherwise you will inevitably find yourself broken to The Rules, as written by people who have otherwise never written anything of note. Another anon has had good ideas with which I don't disagree, but in addition I want to stress that, in my opinion, analysis has never once created an amazing writer despite centuries of ongoing academic effort. Analysis certainly manages to coexist in the mindscapes of (some of) the greats, but it is not necessary. I don't think it even helps, personally, at least not once you let go of your independence of thought, subsume your individualism and start seeing literally anyone as "more expert" than you are. Good writing is, in my opinion, a function primarily of good taste and dedicated practice. The things you like about literature should be deep and enduring love for inexpressible infinitesimals you (and maybe only you) find exhilarating. The things you dislike about literature should be deep and burning hatreds. Above all, you should trust your ability to (eventually) grasp that for which you reach. Be both your own biggest cheerleader and harshest critic when necessary, and recognize that writing something that didn't work does not mean that you will never write something that does. We are all eternal students to no teacher but the act of writing

I like all of this, in various ways. I am not a good writer. I try. I fail on fundamental levels. I write every day; thousands of words. Sometimes it is okay. I find myself aware of a feeling, and it is almost as though when I write I need to get that feeling, or else I did not write well. It is flow, I suppose, to use the shorthand term, though I am not sure I entirely agree with all of that concept.
Curiosity is very important though, I am finding. If I am not curious for what I write, it is not living, and I have to see it or hear it too as I write it, not before I write it, but AS I write it. And I need to dig at it, the images and scenes and everything, words. What's this or that, why did I use that word or event, where's that going? When I have no curiosity, it is dead. Many days it is dead, yet I sit and I type anyway.

As I said I am not a good writer. It may make me sound retarded but I have not found the way to revise my work or edit it. I just write. If I write an entire story in a day, good. If it is fragments, okay. I have concepts and characters I return to, but I write in fragments that contradict each other. It is all a mess with no cohesion. To complete it, revise it, edit it, make it shine. That's where I am struggling to go.

I also wonder if my idea of what I look for, that feeling, that flow, is not merely another limitation I've taken on that shackles me somehow. There are many traps. You just have to do it though. There's no understanding without doing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21378471
I would also like to say that my pursuit of writing, seriously, has changed my life. My mind has shifted from what it was, or what I thought it was. The anon who said writing is a by-product, or should be seen as such, I think had a good idea. Annie Dillard said it similarly: aim for the chopping block, not the wood (this is a wood chopping analogy). Andre Gide said his writing was something like, to paraphrase, the pursuit of his soul, or the growth of his soul. That's good too. With writing seriously I've found that I could never write before due to faults in my own character, or views, or mindset, or state of mind. I had to shift my whole world around to even get myself to sit down each day and write for a few hours. And now I've mastered sitting and typing I find myself blocked with how to return to revise a story, or edit it, and actually make it whole and complete (or as much as can be). And of course with just returning at will to write something, because most days I feel completely thrown about by outside forces that I have to follow or simply waste the day and go limp. I imagine my world is going to have to shift again in order to facilitate these goals, though I have no idea how. One might think it is very simple, point here, do that, make a list, organise, make a plot, follow it, but in practice I find it deeply involved, as though it's all different ways of seeing and being, so getting myself to that place where I can sit on the level I desire and have it all work . . . well that's blocked to me somehow now.

>Horstmann puts forth the theory that mankind has been pre-programmed to eliminate itself in the course of history—and also all its memory of itself—through war (thermonuclear, genetic, biological), genocide, destruction of its sustaining environment, etc. “The final aim of history is a crumbling field of ruins. History, for him, is nothing more than a slaughterhouse . . . “the place of a skull and charnel house of a mad, incurably bloodthirsty slaughtering, flaying and whetting, of an irresistible urge to destroy to the last.” Although inspired by the already extreme philosophy of Philipp Mainländer, Horstmann ends up with an even more explicit solution regarding the problem of human existence. I was thinking this too, that it was just so well-established either in cultural attitudes or (I was thinking) in the forms of the time, since all liberal arts were taught through extreme repetition and adherence to forms for a long time before you were allowed to experiment. But if you look at the 14th and 15th centuries, Europeans went and learned with the masters to learn the prevailing forms, and submitted themselves to painstaking studies too, but then they went and experimented with subjectivism a lot more than the ancients did. Renaissance painters packed more experimentation and subjectivity into 250 years than the ancients had in a thousand.

The ancients also seem more interested in technical refinement than formal experimentation. Panofsky says it took them a few centuries into the post-classical Hellenistic period to even begin appreciating painting and sculpture the way we do or Renaissance people did, as a medium for individual geniuses rather than just highly talented craftsmen.

>>21381702
We have a pretty good idea of what works existed even when they don't survive, and a good idea of Hellenistic culture. You're treating Hellenistic Rome like it's Ur III. Also what you're saying only makes sense if there's a necessary or obvious correlation between epic/grand style and being considered high art, which is exactly what the thread is asking... Why is it that we would eagerly save an impenetrably subjective poem or letter, and consider it an artistic classic? You're just raising one of the premises the thread is already based on

But also, the ancients DID have a highly subjective and "ephemeral" genre in a sense, the genre of letter-writing. But their letter-writing was often essayistic, and even in highly informal subjective letters they still portrayed themselves in very archetypal, stark ways. Compare that with modern letters meant for publication. Someone like Lawrence feels infinitely more of a "right" to bare his soul in all its weirdness and particularity than an ancient writer did, and we don't find this disgusting or merely flawed like an ancient reader might. This difference is what the question is all about.

How do you take notes when reading/what do you take notes of?

I recently graduated college and didn't learn anything. When I was in college, I took notes when I read. However, those notes that I took were usually just the pg number of various quotes that I could use to illustrate the point of a paper that I was writing. So, /lit, how do you take notes?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21381429
good question anon

note-taking's pretty individual, everyone has their own angle and shit. if I'm taking notes on a text I'll underline/scribble in the margins and if the text is particularly dense/thorny/provocative I'll read with a notebook beside me. keep asking yourself why? something in a book annoys you -- why? try and figure it out with pen and paper. you love something in a book -- why? trace your idea. don't try and make your notes deep or meaningful or smart. write down what you're thinking, what confuses you, what excites you. remember, no one will read them but you

posts.com:
When, in disgrace with fortune and men’s eyes,
I all alone beweep my outcast state,
And trouble deaf heaven with my bootless cries,
And look upon myself, and curse my fate,
Wishing me like to one more rich in hope,
Featur’d like him, like him with friends possess’d,
Desiring this man’s art and that man’s scope,
With what I most enjoy contented least;
Yet in these thoughts myself almost despising,
Haply I think on thee, and then my state,
Like to the lark at break of day arising
From sullen earth, sings hymns at heaven’s gate;
For thy sweet love remember’d such wealth brings
That then I scorn to change my state with kings.

The description of the beloved is so powerful, but there is no direct compliments. It could basically apply to anyone. I also like the vulnerability shown.

Sonnet 20:
By William Shakespeare

A woman’s face with nature’s own hand painted
Hast thou, the master-mistress of my passion;
A woman’s gentle heart, but not acquainted
With shifting change as is false women’s fashion;
An eye more bright than theirs, less false in rolling,
Gilding the object whereupon it gazeth;
A man in hue, all hues in his controlling,
Which steals men’s eyes and women’s souls amazeth.
And for a woman wert thou first created,
Till nature as she wrought thee fell a-doting,
And by addition me of thee defeated
By adding one thing to my purpose nothing.
But since she pricked thee out for women's pleasure,
Mine be thy love and thy love’s use their treasure.

I just reached 55,000 words in the book I have been writing since January. How the fuck do people put 50k into a brand new work entirely in November?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21381463
Writing a book is a big undertaking, and it's normal to feel overwhelmed or frustrated at times. The key is to stay focused and motivated, and to set aside regular time each day to work on your book. You might also find it helpful to break your writing goals down into smaller, more manageable chunks. For example, instead of focusing on the overall goal of reaching 55,000 words, you could aim to write 1,000 words per day. This can make the process feel less daunting and can help you make steady progress towards completing your book.

It's also important to remember that everyone works at their own pace, and what might seem fast to you might be perfectly normal for someone else. It's not a race, and the important thing is to focus on creating a book that you're proud of, regardless of how long it takes. If you're feeling stuck or struggling to find the motivation to keep going, you might find it helpful to talk to other writers or to seek out support from a writing group or coach. These people can provide valuable guidance and support, and can help you stay on track and motivated. Good luck with your book!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The Christian religion belongs to no specific national stock: the Christian dogma addresses purely - human nature. Only in so far as it has seized in all its purity this content common to all men, can a people call itself Christian in truth. However, a people can make nothing fully its own but what becomes possible for it to grasp with its inborn feeling, and to grasp in such a fashion that in the New it finds its own familiar self again. Upon the realm of aesthetics and philosophic Criticism it may be demonstrated, almost palpably, that it was predestined for the German spirit to seize and assimilate the Foreign, the primarily remote from it, in utmost purity and objectivity of intuition (in höchster objektiver Reinheit der Anschauung). One may aver, without exaggeration, that the Antique would have stayed unknown, in its now universal world-significance, had the German spirit not recognised and expounded it. The Italian made as much of the Antique his own, as he could copy and remodel; the Frenchman borrowed from this remodelling, in his turn, whatever caressed his national sense for elegance of Form: the German was the first to apprehend its purely-human originality, to seize therein a meaning quite aloof from usefulness, but therefore of the only use for rendering the Purely-human. Through its inmost understanding of the Antique, the German spirit arrived at the capability of restoring the Purely-human itself to its pristine freedom; not employing the antique form to display a certain given 'stuff,' but moulding the necessary new form itself through an employment of the antique conception of the world. To recognise this plainly, let anyone compare Goethe's Iphigenia with that of Euripides. One may say that the true idea of the Antique has existed only since the middle of the eighteenth century, since Winckelmann and Lessing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Now, that the German would have apprehended the Christian dogma in equally preeminent clearness and purity, and would have raised it to the only valid Confession-of-faith, just as he had raised the Antique to a dogma in Æsthetics,—this can not be demonstrated. Perhaps on evolutionary paths unknown to us, and by us unimaginable, he might have arrived hereat; and certain attributes would make it appear that, of all others, the German spirit was called thereto. In any case 'tis easier for us to see what hindered its solution of the problem, since we recognise what enabled it to solve a like one in the region of Æsthetics. For here there was nothing to hinder it: Æsthetics were neither interfered with by the State, nor converted to its ends. With Religion things were otherwise: it had become an interest of the State, and this State-interest obtained its meaning and its guidance, not from the German, but quite definitely from the un-German, the Romanic spirit. It was the incalculable misfortune of Germany that, about the time when the German spirit was ripening for its task upon that high domain, the legitimate State-interests of all German peoples were entrusted to the counsels of a prince to whom the German spirit was a total stranger, to the most thorough-paced representative of the un-German, Romanic State-idea: Charles the Fifth, King of Spain and Naples, hereditary Archduke of Austria, elected Romish Kaiser and Sovereign of the German Reich, devoured by ambition for world-supremacy, which would actually have fallen to him if he had been able to master France,—this sovereign felt no other interest in Germany, than to weld it with his empire, an iron-bound monarchy like Spain.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>21380207
>>21380275
Don Quixote is long but, stylistically speaking, the prose is very straightforward and easy to understand if you use a modern translation, like Grossman's (the only parts in the book that will give you trouble are the parts that are meant to be confusing in a humorous way; for example, in the second part, there are times when Sancho will string together sayings and witticisms so densely that Don Quixote tells him to shut the fuck up because he can't understand what the hell he's getting at). But as a novel, it is very episodic and very simple compared to even genre fiction today, so it might be underwhelming for you. The best place to start reading "literary fiction" will be Charles Dickens and John Steinbeck.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21380207
>pulpiest scifi/fantasy/horror
SIMPLICIUS. It's a picaresque, 30 Years War, and a holy fool retard child going through it. That or Don Quixote, just as silly. Might just do a chapter a day of DQ and take it in episodically while you're reading through the others. Alfred Jarry's Ubu play is surreal/absurd political satire from the interwar period that would crossover interest wise.

Robert E. Howard & Olaf Stapelton, if you hadn't already, definitely in line with your interests. Maybe go through canon early-mid 20th century Noir & Westerns as well, Maltese Falcon, that sort of thing.

Non-pulpy horror -- Ambrose Bierce shorts, Edgar Allen Poe, Robert Chambers, there's a lot out there.

Scifi -- same thing, 2001 (the film isn't an adaptation, but was written concurrently from early script drafts & Kubrick retaining editorial discretion); Dune, Virus (Komatsu),

Fantasy: CS Lewis (That Hideous Strength, dystopian/scifish), Lewis Carrol, Frank Baum's Wizard of Oz series, -- and the epics are always solid, read the Sagas, Kalevala, ect.


>>21380207

I'll try to put it as simply: one finds things like the zombie Psyduck or Shadow the Hedgehog using guns while mildly swearing "absurd" and "impossible to take seriously" because, when it comes down to it, they start off from concepts that are close to what is commonly accepted as "kid-appropriate" (not even "kid friendly"!), then add elements that are at odds with it... but in such a way that it is clearly "not mature" in itself!
Just because a Sonic character brandishes a realistic gun doesn't mean it suddenly becomes a Call of Duty clone: if the opponents are still purely evil demons and/or faceless mercenaries with little reason behind their existence, the character is still essentially a simple one, the color palette is still colorful, and the effect of the gun is the same as using a spin dash or whatever, you just have given a things that looks mature to a character within a setting that isn't.
If an Asterìx comic directly showed the rape of a woman called Slutrix, by a man called Incelix, and the rest of the comic had Obelix using his superstrenght to track the guy down and then punch him into the sky like the Roman soldiers, all the while Asterìx and Vitastatix comfort Slutrix with shopping, it wouldn't be mature because the rape would not be treated seriously in itself.

If Captain Haddock was presented catching HIV from eating bushmeat, and the comic, while mantaining the canon personalities, talked about it realistically, it would be mature, yes, but it also could be considered "cringe" because it's trying to process a real issue through the lens of fictional characters.


Shit, this one issue also affects more "adult" comics too, because for example at no point in Marvel comics Reed Richards ever canonically tries to solve world hunger or cure cancer is because that would trivialize the actual problem.

posts.com:
Its usually a pretty transparent admission that your ideas are too simplistic or even idiotic to hold up if you applied them to a complex real-world scenario; your whole work becomes a cope to let you jack off over your presumed intelligence.
You can have a work that takes a definite partisan stance or expounds an ideological theme (the universal standard theme of good vs evil is partisan, after all), but you should avoid writing these works as explicit 'answers' to concrete, real-world issues. You cheapen the work and cage your writing in what the audience will likely percieve as myopia.
As for whether it 'insults' the audience, I'd argue that anyone who feels slighted by an artist's production, if they were not themselves directly targeted by that artist, is revealing themselves to be ideologically captured and a retard.

"Bibliomancy, stichomancy or libromancy is a form of divination that seeks to know the future by randomly selecting a passage from a book, frequently a sacred text."

Has /lit/ tried out Bibliomancy, with physical books, e-Books, search engines, etc.?

I'll copy/paste an excerpt from Damien Echols' "Angels and Archangels" for you guys to experiment with for those interested. In short, it has you invoke an entity and then searching the surface web for a result to your query.

---

>Let’s start with a practice that people have been doing for thousands of years, mostly with holy books (namely, the Bible and the Quran), but also with revered works of literature (in particular, the epics of Homer and Virgil). Whenever they felt like they needed some divine guidance or a higher form of advice, they’d flip open the chosen text at random, place their finger down without looking, and glean some meaning from whatever word or passage their finger found. If you resonate with the texts mentioned above (or any others, for that matter), feel free to adopt the following practice for them, but this modern take on bibliomancy employs the great unfolding text that most of us use all the time: the internet.

>1. Consider the issue or topic you want assistance with.

>2. Invoke an angel or archangel you either feel connected to or whom you think is appropriate to this particular issue.

>3. Initiate a web search either by using keywords or employing a random content service.

>4. See what comes up. Try not to offhandedly dismiss the results. I’ve found that what arises when I employ this practice sometimes won’t make sense for days or weeks.

---

https://occult-world.com/bibliomancy-divinations/

https://youtu.be/I8DedHRLEeQ

But on Sunday evening, and with the echo of the phantom hooves still crashing soundlessly in the duskfilled study, he watches quietly the puny, unhorsed figure moving with that precarious and meretricious cleverness of animals balanced on their hinder legs; that cleverness of which the man animal is so fatuously proud and which constantly betrays him by means of natural laws like gravity and ice, and by the very extraneous objects which he has himself invented, like motor cars and furniture in the dark, and the very refuse of his own eating left upon floor or pavement; and he thinks quietly how right the ancients were in making the horse an attribute and symbol of warriors and kings, when he sees the man in the street pass the low sign and turn into his gate and approach the house. He sits forward then, watching the man come up the dark walk toward the dark door; he hears the man stumble heavily at the dark bottom step. “Byron Bunch,” he says. “In town on Sunday night. Byron Bunch in town on Sunday.”

>>21370285
>he can't tell the difference between these styles
I must say, if you present these two as similar you have the literary equivalent of tone-deafness, in my humble opinion.

How would you say this observant walk through a building, almost clinical in its detail, is in any way similar beyond "a simple knack for writing" to the at worst melodramatic use of an environment to present a sort of mood? The Faulkner is one breathless whispering of a man's observation of his surroundings in their relation to himself, whereas Nabokov's stretch is an almost irreverent and comical observation of the bibelots contained in some manse, cut into by parentheses, asides, and in a way, a sort of miniature tour. The Faulkner, again, has a texture of emotion infused into every string, whilst Nabokov keeps a sort of academic distance. Take the description of the trees in either example, Faulkner's trees are an environmental effect, part of a shadow cast by an unsteady and harsh light, he uses his trees to paint a picture, but one with "bitten shadows", "unwinded maples", nothing is without its verbal ally to prop it up, whilst Nabokov's tree is similarly describing a shadow cast by a tree but in a very different manner, clinical to the detail, what tree it is, what type of shadow it is casting (large leaf, contrast that with bitten, nabokov enters into detail to describe almost stubbornly that this tree has a leafy shadow, big surprise) even a lengthy, texture-of-text upheaving aside from Ada to describe the root of this tree in name.

No, their styles do not mix, perhaps at a certain superficial perspective, but from where I sit (not, perhaps, very far from the surface) there are distinct examples of these two authors being worlds apart in what and how they use their language, how they build their sentences, to what extent they describe what they do, the pace, the amount of emotion that is allowed to seep from the author themselves, and the colors they use (namely, that faulkner doesn't use any, whilst nabokov uses at least one within the first sentence of the excerpt to "fill in" the blanks). Perhaps a possible notable similarity is that they both use sentences. Which isn't exactly a glaring example of stylistic kinship.

further still, faulkner has a clumsiness to him, soundless echoes? not a hyphen in sight, either, also a portmanteau in "duskfilled".

nabokov's contains, somewhat, the casual texture of conversation, with idiosyncrasies, (note the 'thank Log', probably further still an inside joke, which adds to the depth of the prose here) while Faulkner's presentation is direct. There is an undercurrent, a re-readability, a suggestion that upon return something may be seen that was not noticed before inherent in Nabokov's style, a camera obscura. I have a sort of pet thought that Nabokov particularly captures things in so many layers so that it contains *all* things, to almost exhaust the reader, to fill up his eyes, to slip things through subconsciously, and to provide us with that sense, again, that we may have missed something, a sort of I, Spy. Faulkner gives us his direct approach, this happens, this means this to the man, this sounds this way, and when he does try to insert detail, it strikes a sort of false tone, the "that precarious and meretricious", if one could pin his style down in his own words, he's done it here. It evokes, to be sure, it is talented without question, and I personally greatly enjoy Faulkner in the correct moods, but to blindly attempt to disagree with Nabokov's critisms by attempting to squeeze together their styles (poorly i might add) is a bit facile, let's be frank. Nabokov is a jokester, he breaks Ada winding monologues with Van's comical off chance remarks. The tedious spatial descriptions are peppered with old Van's wit (tonguetied Ada, intolerably bored Van, Van's burning bladder) not only does it convey the awkwardness of first encounters, all the unimportant chatter and silent observation, but by it's contrast defines both characters. Pragmatic Van, cynically twisting his memories to rewrite the past (the only emotion in the scene is retroactively written in by small comments) and "innocent", pretentious Ada. The key here is Nabokov's sense of humor, wordplay and comic timing.

>>21370858
>Anything that intimates a higher meaning behind the world of appearances (Faulkner, Conrad, Bellow) he rejected. His stories take place in a materialist world full of colours and textures but without transcendence, the universe to him was a beautiful and cruel arrangement of coincidences.
He did indeed criticize authors for “pasting up a cardboard Christ in the story to give it meaning,” but a work like Pale Fire, for instance, is precisely at its core about questions like life-after-death, synchronicities, parapsychology and the like (even if they’re regarded wryly, subversively, satirically and in a postmodern fashion, with reversals and blunders which deflate seeming supernatural occurrences).

See the message Hazel gets from a “dancing light” in the barnyard:

pada ata lane pad not ogo old wart alan ther tale feur far rant lant tal told

The book doesn’t explain this message (Kinbote is unable to make sense of it), but Nabokov himself translated it in a letter after the novel’s publication. When read aloud, the message loosely sounds like an instruction for father not to cross the lane to the Goldsworth house to hear a tale of a foreign land—read this way, the light relaying the message knows the fate that awaits Hazel’s father (he gets shot after crossing the street to Kinbote’s house, which Judge Goldsworth owns).

>The verbal starkness that so often muddily refers back to some primitive or biblical/spiritual meaning is just a disguise for a lack of technical and unacademic rigor.
It doesn't refer to any primitive or biblical spiritual meaning actually. You were just filtered. He makes it clear repeatedly. The suggestion in McCarthy's metaphor is an important part of how narrative is made, but it is always dissociative, referring to something that doesn't readily resolves into a coherent narrative. Pressure of meaning David Holloway called it. This is even explicitly referenced in Blood Meridian. When The Judge and the idiot are being alluded to as King Lear and Fool:
>It was the judge and the imbecile. They were both of them naked and they neared through the desert dawn like beings of a mode little more than tangential to the world at large, their figures now quick with clarity and now fugitive in the strangeness of that same light. Like things whose very portent renders them ambiguous. Like things so charged with meaning that their forms are dimmed.
Their true forms (the judge and the idiot) have "become dimmed" in favor of the associative suggestions of metaphor (charged with meaning; king lear and fool here, a few more iirc). Similar meta suggestions are sprinkled all across BM, and is McCarthy's true philosophy. In kekule problem he said:
>the world is only made of facts, it is us who channel it into a narrative.
Or something to that accord. That is very much McCarthy's mode in BM. A laconic clinical description of physical world with sudden flights into associative imagery. BM is in the truest sense about the process of meaning-making and not any greater spiritual transcendence beyond the veener of reality (which is why there is absolutely no agreed upon interpretation of the book, a la Pale fire somewhat but McCarthy doesn't have to rely on obvious parlor tricks)
>a vague impression of the author's tone that even HE would struggle to clarify in any way
I think you greatly overvalue your intelligence. Those with enough cognitive intelligence can see what McCarthy is trying to do. You trying to suggest that because you couldn't make head or tail of it somehow means that even the author wouldn't is a dumb as hell claim to make. This is also the problem I think, McCarthy unlike other writers, Nabokov included requires cognition to appreciate. No amount of reference or trivia (no hazel trees?) hunting will make readers see his greater aesthetic. And its funny you call Nabokov a scientist when McCarthy's aesthetic is far more "scientific" inasmuch it serves a deep vision of the world which, even if we make concessions for Nabokov's hidden spirituality and philosophy of creation, is frankly on a completely different level to what Vladdy is trying to sell his audience. Ironically, the philosophers in his books argue against a transcendent view of reality, for the people who mistakenly think he is in the same vein as Dostoevsky or Faulkner.

I'm not saying that Faulkner is as good a poet as Shakespeare, or that his poetic style is similar to Shakespeare's, but I can't understand how Nabokov sees as flaws in Faulkner's work things that he praises in Shakespeare.

>Bombastic language
>Impossible dialogues
>extravagant “deep” conversations
>combination of starkness and hyperbole

All this is found in all of Shakespeare's plays. Language is never natural, dialogues are always "impossible" because human beings don't speak that way. Shakespeare's "deep thoughts" are often commonplaces that have been repeated thousands of times, but which Shakespeare is now repeating in what is perhaps the most beautiful poetic language ever created (although it remains "extravagant 'deep' conversations" nonetheless). The bombast happens in every play, so much so that if Shakespeare becomes interested in a particular topic or image, he forgets the play and the character that is speaking and gets more concerned with writing great poetry than creating a "mimesis" of the world.

I can understand Nabokov saying that he fails to consider Faulkner's language great poetry, but only the attempts of a pseudo-poet trying to write great poetry. But the criticisms of artificiality, of bombast, of pretentiousness, of exaggeration: this is all exactly the same as what we find in Shakespeare.

Not just Shakespeare. Nabokov liked Moby-Dick, and the same criticisms he leveled at Faulkner can be leveled at Melville. Perhaps in this case the difference is that he likes Melville's poetry but not Faulkner's.
