>>21370285
>behind him seem to from a distance faint clear he can hear a sound he sees he would have recognised the echo of soundlessly he watches quietly when he sees he sits watching he hears
Nabokov wouldn't use these words. He's willing to be direct.
Faulkner wants you to know that this here is the observer, those are his observations, and all the way over there you have reality. It wouldn't do to get them confused!
Nabokov homes straight in on qualic memory. He isn't going to say that Van looked at the tree that Ada showed him, or that the tree's leaves' shadows seem large to him. We know it's Van and we know that he's being given a tour. Calling the shadows large would be more than sufficient, and what you really want to explain is how the leaves overlap the threshold, because that's the sort of detail that sticks in your memory. The rest is implied.
This is very deliberate, not just for this novel (a fake autobiography of sorts) but in general. In pic related (from http://www.kafka.org/index.php?id=191,209,0,0,1,0) he claims that so-called "objective reality" doesn't even exist. It's not so strange that he'd be turned off by somebody who goes in the other direction.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21366821
It's the hours. I'm a student, but I'm going to try and get a comfy government job through a little bit of nepotism. If I could work in a firm for flat 40 hours a week and leave it at the door, I would do it. However, that's usually insurance law which doesn't really pay that much. Everything else is incredibly deadline intensive, and the clients want work done yesterday.

Also, the biggest problem with the practice of law is the billable hour. Firms might set you a target that says you need 1800 billable hours a year. You might think 'woo, nice, that's the same as the average hours worked by US employees, and lawyers get paid a lot so it's fine.' It's not fine. Just because you have been at work for an hour does not mean that's a billable hour. It's entirely common to be at work for 8 hours but only bill 5, in which case you either BILL for 11 (work for 14+) the next day to catch catch up, or more commonly work on the weekend to make up those extra unbilled hours.

Also, 1800 hours is not a common target for big firms. Firms that pay a decent wage relative to hours worked demand 2100+ billable hours a year. Which factoring in commute and all this shit means you have been 'at work' for 3000+. There's a very good paper about this if you want to know more about why never to work for a law firm.

https://law.yale.edu/sites/default/files/area/department/cdo/document/billable_hour.pdf

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21368316
Depends. Questions like yours are why constitutional law is its own field. Interpretations vary. For example, there was another case of a guy who stole mail. The court decided that an appropriate punishment was to make him stand out in public holding a sign saying "I stole mail, this is my punishment," (among other things). The ensuing appeals all were about the constitutionality of humiliation. Ultimately it was decided that shame is permissible if it is an externality of a punishment's goal, it can't be the sole goal.

I'm not trying to defend Justice Thomas, I dont even agree with his opinion there, just trying to say that there are a lot of different angles to getting at this concept of what is "cruel and unusual," . To me, Cali's 3 strikes rule is borderline. And has more to do with theories of punishment than constitutional law, but even that relies on how fluid you think the constitutional ought to be.

Too many moving parts. Thats why we go to school for this shit, I guess.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21368056
>>21368316
>>21368471
It's quite interesting actually and I happen to know a fair bit about the specific topic. Thomas and Scalia both believe the 8th Amendment has no guarantee of proportionality, which is at odds with pretty much everyone else on the Court (other conservative justices like Alito and O'conner reject their arguments; I think O'Conner's plurality opinion in Ewing gives the best argument against Thomas's theory from a somewhat originalist/textualist perspective). There's about a dozen dissenting opinions where Thomas and Scalia cite each other about how the majority is constantly exceeding its authority, which are funny to read, particularly Scalia's.

Thomas actually does think proportionality exists, but is only relevant in capital cases, or (maybe) fines/bail/whippings. Also worth noting that his upper bound for what would be proportionate is something like executing a seven year old for stealing 50 dollars worth of merchandise. Maybe adjusted for inflation if he were feeling particularly generous. The gist of the argument as I understand it is that (a) the framers never used any language to indicate proportionality in sentencing, (b) the 8th Amendment was meant to protect against torture and little else, and (c) prison sentences were never really covered under the 8th Amendment since they didn't exist in 1790; only of relevance is executions, whippings, public shaming, etc. Honestly I might be somewhat incorrect here, but yes, it's exactly as insane as it sounds.

Honestly it's a mediocre argument in my opinion, since the actual text of the 8th Amendment implies proportionality in fines and bail ("excessive" implies proportionality), other historically relevant documents like the English Bill of Rights contain explicit proportionality guarantees, and when dealing with how cruel any punishment is the idea of proportionality is implicit.

Thomas goes over the argument in his dissent in Graham v. Florida. You can ignore everything about how unusual the punishment is (number of states, etc.) since he doesn't think the analysis the majority is using should exist at all, unless you find that debate interesting in its own right.
>https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/560/48/

I've never met a single judge or lawyer who is particularly progressive, and I've worked for union-side law firms and currently work for a progressive union. The most annoying progressives tend to be people who don't have decision making power. I just don't see rampant progressivism as a real issue that affects the law. Progressivism is more of an imagined threat than a real one.

>It also gives the Supreme Court a lot of power to justify decisions based on "current Canadian values", which they themselves are empowered to define. No wonder they have rejected originalist thinking outright; they'd be foolish not too desu.
I find the SCC treads pretty lightly in that regard, and they have to base it on the evidentiary record from the trial court. I also think that regardless of ideology, smart judges can read whatever they want into the law. Whether it's originalism or living tree, there's a lot of power in the Supreme Court.

>Originalism would at least temper outlandish decisions by putting some interpretive restraint on the incredible power they've been enabled to wield.
I can't name any outlandish progressive SCC decision in recent Canadian history. I find that they are generally very cautious and tend towards being conservative. In general, I see the law as a conservative institution, and I think most Canadian judges treat it that way.

Herb [/hɜːrb/]

Noun

1. To be whack. Worthy of being mocked. Weak, chumpish, and generally to be avoided.

2. Mocking term of endearment for friends and/or rivals.

The term originated in New York City, with a national ad campaign by Burger King at the time featuring the tagline: "Don't be a herb, get the Whopper." In this instance, Herb was a like a neologistic mix between "nerd" and a "moron."

>"Yo wassup, herbs -- what time we drinking?"

>"Man, this party got way too many herbs, I'm out."

>"That nigga ask way too many questions -- he a straight herb, son."

by RumpyDooDoo, December 7, 2012
